publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M52. Anon. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 19p. Paginated [1]-19, wanting p. 5, 14 (two p. 15).

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Anon.
"For many centuries after Britain became an island" the hist

orian says " "the untamed forest was king." Its
mosit moist and
mssy mossy floor was hidden from heavens eye by a close drawn
curtain of innumerable treetops. " On the matted bough

innumerable birds
snag sang ; but their song was only heard by a

few skin clad hunters in the
claetings clearings . Did the desire

to sing come to one of those barbarians savages because he
geard heard the
birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a
moment? Anyhow, the tree was felled; some sort of hut
was made from its branches; and the clearing became larger;

the birds
f er fewer ; and the human voice sang instead. The first
songs are out of door songs; spring songs; summer songs;
winter songs.

quote.l: The lutel foul hath hire wyl
By a bank as I lay
And me thought in her lay
She said winter was past, hey ho!

p.l: They were out of door songs, because there was no
comfort indoors, little light, and no books. The eye
therefore was more active in in ourselves. The eye is the
young sense; the sense that is attached to the body.

Now and then, by
chooisng choosing a view carefully to shut out
a chimney or a bungalow, we can still see a fragment of
of what they saw-- a flat fen, reed whispering, water
logged; or a down still covered with turf only.
On the down is the green scar still, to mark the
road along which the travellers came, past the circle where
they were buried; past the stone that marks the meeting place
or the burial place.
xxxxxxxAnon sings because love and spring make him
vocal or the horror of winter dark But, who listens? Somebody
heard that particular song, or it would not have been written

down. The singer then had his
audeince audience ; but the audience was
so little interested in his name that he never thought to
give it.
It was the printed book with the authors name attached that
was the death of Anon. after thatThe audience was separated from
the singer. After that (1478) the sing was attached to
the singer. Anon gives place to James or Thomas; he lives in
in a house; and he has books.
The heart of this vast proliferation of printed
pages is the song. The song has the same power over the
reader in the 20th century as over the hearer in the

11th. To enjoy singing, to enjoy
h aring hearing the song,
must be the deepest rooted and tough of human instincts.
It is an instinct of self-preservation, for only when we
put two and two together to we overcome dissolution. Two

lines, two words, two
bri cks bricks make way against oblivion.
Making whatever it is gives us life; and the passion
with which we seek for these creations, and attempt to
make them, is of a piece with the instinct that
sets us preserving our bodies from wet, or cold.
But with the printing press came into existence
forces that cover over the original song--books
themselves and the readers of books. Could we at this
this moment X ray the singers mind we shound find

a nimbus surrounding the song; a
st eam stream of

influences to which so many ugly
abstarct abstract names have been
given-- influences of society; of education; of

class; material; economic of
econmic economic stress. So many are they and so
obscure that we may call them nonsense names--
say Nin, Crot and Pully. Nin Crot and Pully are always

at their task.
?ore More and more complex

at their work--tugging, obscuring, distracting.
invisble invisible
to the sufferer himself often. More and more complex
they become as time passes. The song is only to be discovered
ixmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx instaneously; in a flash
of recognition; some say they feel it when their beards
brsitle bristle ; others that a thrill runs down the nerves of the
thigh. But the song is there still...
Waves...

one of those commentators who tell us so much about the

and ??? for him painful; they were ??? reminders of a savagery of low

In the background, mxmxmxmxxx of
Har isons Harrison's mind stood
the Greeks and the romans; Henrcus Cornelius Agrippa;

Suetonius; Pliny, Cicero. Those were the
anicenits ancients who

occupied the same place in Harrisons mind that the
Elizabetha Elizabethans
occupy in our minds. The readers of his time read the
classics, Those were the valuable books that

were chained to the
sleves shelves in college libraries. The
leanred learned
read them; and the nobles too. "...our ancient ladies of the

court" were to be found reading the holy
scrpitures scriptures as

they did their
needlwork needlework ; and histories;

The great Elizabethan house is still in
exist nce existence ,
sxpxmx standing in its green island of high grass, separated
often from the high road only by a sxmxmxx dip in the

Inside all is kept as if the Queen were expected. ????

The rooms are

lived in. The upright
Elizabethna Elizabethan chairs stand round the wall.
Their fringes and their tapestry is not much faded.
The great carved tables are polished nad lustrous.
The carved ??? chests and cupboards look brand new.

Even the toys and
kicknacks knick-knacks have survived intact :/ inlaid

boxes; Here are the inlaid work boxes, and the that the Queen
nahdle needled?
as she sat upright on the faded pink day couch. And there,

bel ied bellied lute or theorbo,
on which she played, still resonant. & the varnished pear shaped lute upon which the Queen once played. The floor
is strewn with rugs; the windows curtained with
silv r thraed silver thread brocades; and here are the cut glass Venice
chandeliers ????? which lighted this byegone company.

But where are the Elizabethans people? They were more
ehmepral ephemeral

than their possessions. Human Life has
recded receded
fromthis from this
convoluted iridescent shell; with its fringes and its laces,
